title: Scott Morrison says prayer a reminder of our vulnerability
text:
"What I like about prayer and what is so important about us coming together in our Parliament and praying, is prayer gives us a reminder of our humility and our vulnerability, and that forms a unity," Mr Morrison said.

"Because there’s certainly one thing we all have in common, whether we sit in the green or red chairs in this place, or anywhere else, and that is our human frailty.

"It is one of the great misconceptions, I think, of religion that there’s something about piety. It is the complete reverse. Faith, religion, is actually first and foremost an expression of our human frailty and vulnerability and an understanding that there are things far bigger than each of us."

Mr Morrison, who was launching a book on prayer, said he had visited a bushfire-ravaged town in northern NSW on Sunday and "our prayers must also be with them and all of those affected by all of the natural disasters which in this country we face with great frequency".

During his recent trip to the US, Mr Morrison visited a Pentecostal church to worship, the National Capital Community Church, whose pastor Mark Batterson has given sermons arguing that pre-marital sex and homosexuality are sins.

But in question time, Mr Morrison was subjected to several questions over reports he tried to get another Pentecostal church leader, Hillsong founder Brian Houston, into the state dinner hosted by President Donald Trump.

The Wall Street Journal reported last month that the White House had rejected Mr Morrison's request Mr Houston be invited. Mr Morrison at the time tried to brush off the claim by saying he did not comment on "gossip", but did not deny the story.

Mr Houston was criticised in the findings of the 2014 royal commission into institutional responses to child sexual abuse for failing to alert police about allegations his father, Frank, had sexually assaulted children, and had a conflict of interest when he assumed responsibility for dealing with the accusations.

Mr Morrison told Parliament invitations for the event were issued by the White House and he did not comment on unsourced reports.

"If they are suggesting anything serious or casting any aspersions on the

individual which is the subject of the question, then perhaps I suggest they go and attend that church and they explain their concerns directly to their parishioners," he said.
description: The prime minister says prayer can bring MPs together and deal with the challenges facing the world.
